A White Historian Claimed That Black People ‘Had No History.’ This Trailblazing Scholar Dedicated His Life to Proving Otherwise
Carter G. Woodson, the “father of Black history,” founded the celebration now known as Black History Month in 1926. A prolific writer and activist, he viewed his efforts to educate the public as a “life-and-death struggle”
In February 1926, the eminent Black scholar Carter G. Woodson called on communities across the United States to observe a weeklong celebration of Black history.
Woodson urged members of the public to ask “every church, school, lodge and club” in their locality to host talks and events, and request that libraries stock up on “books setting forth dispassionately what the Negro has thought and felt and attempted and accomplished.” The historian added, “Remember that the preservation of the records of the Negro is not the duty of one man, not the duty of any particular group of men. It is the duty of us all.”
His call to action marked the first Negro History Week, a precursor to today’s Black History Month. The celebration debuted at a time when few scholars viewed Black history as worthy of study. As Samir Meghelli, a curator at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture (NMAAHC), says in an email, Woodson “was often confronted with the bigotry of the historical profession: the near absence of African Americans in history books or, when present, only as never having made meaningful contributions to history.”
Described by many as “the father of Black history,” Woodson strongly disputed white historians’ dismissal of Black experiences. “If a race has no history, if it has no worthwhile tradition, it becomes a negligible factor in the thought of the world, and it stands in danger of being exterminated,” he argued in a 1926 essay.
He “believed that if he didn’t document the chronicles of Black people and people from the African diaspora, if he didn’t write this record, that Black people wouldn’t be acknowledged with their humanity,” says Pero G. Dagbovie, a historian at Michigan State University and the author of multiple books about Woodson. He sought to reach everyday Americans, educating “Black people, Black youth, so they could take pride in themselves,” Dagbovie adds.
Negro History Week’s establishment was just one act in a lifetime dedicated to the celebration of Black history. Woodson also founded an association and an accompanying journal dedicated to the African American experience; wrote dozens of books, journal articles, newspaper columns and book reviews; and mentored a generation of Black historians. As Smithsonian Secretary Lonnie G. Bunch III wrote in a 2015 NMAAHC blog post, “No one has played a greater role in helping all Americans know the Black past than Carter G. Woodson.”
Woodson’s early life and education
When Woodson was a child growing up in the Jim Crow South, he rarely attended school. Born to formerly enslaved sharecroppers in Virginia in 1875, Woodson spent much of his youth helping out on the family farm, making it to the classroom only on days when the weather was too poor for him to work outside.
Despite his lack of formal schooling, the young Woodson exhibited a passion for learning. “His mother was among the minority of enslaved who were literate,” says Meghelli, “and he considered his father—although illiterate and without formal education—a powerful example of what was possible when facing seemingly insurmountable challenges with purpose and determination.” (Woodson’s father, James Henry Woodson, escaped from slavery during the Civil War, joining up with the Union Army and leading his fellow soldiers to nearby Confederate supply depots. After the conflict ended, he worked as a sharecropper, eventually making enough money to purchase a 20-acre farm.)
While working as a coal miner in West Virginia in the early 1890s, Woodson befriended a Black Civil War veteran who was unable to read or write. Determined to stay informed about current events, the man asked Woodson to read the latest newspapers and books out loud to him and his friends. “In this circle, the history of the [Black] race was discussed frequently, and my interest in penetrating the past of my people was deepened and intensified,” Woodson later recalled.
After enrolling in high school at age 20, Woodson graduated in under two years. He went on to obtain a bachelor’s degree from Berea College before teaching briefly in the Philippines, which had recently been annexed as a U.S. colony. Returning home, Woodson received a second bachelor’s degree and a master’s degree from the University of Chicago before enrolling in a history PhD program at Harvard University in 1908.
Woodson “learned to really respect the power of education by being denied it,” says Dagbovie. “He grew up poor, and he saw education as being a window for mobility.” John T. Fowler II, a park ranger at the Carter G. Woodson Home National Historic Site in Washington, D.C., adds: “Even though he had to go and work and help his family, he never lost that thirst, that zeal for learning. When he got the opportunity to go to school, he took advantage of it, and, essentially, the rest is history.”
At Harvard, Woodson trained under white historians who expressed racist views toward Black Americans. According to an account by one of Woodson’s protégés, the father of Black history traced his life’s mission in part to a conversation with the historian Edward Channing, who told his students that “the Negro had no history.” Woodson disputed this claim, arguing that “no people lacked a history.” Channing tasked Woodson with proving him wrong—a challenge that the younger historian readily accepted.
Woodson’s efforts to preserve Black history
Woodson graduated from Harvard in 1912, becoming the second Black American to receive a PhD from the university, after the celebrated scholar W.E.B. Du Bois in 1895. He was also the only person of enslaved parentage to earn a PhD in history from an American higher education institution.
As Woodson entered the world of academia, he repeatedly found himself barred from white-dominated spaces, including the annual meeting of the nation’s premier history organization. At the same time, Woodson noticed a distinct lack of scholarly resources dedicated to African American history. In 1915, he set out to redress this imbalance by founding the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History (now the Association for the Study of African American Life and History, or ASALH). Because white journals and academic institutions refused to acknowledge Black history, Woodson decided to create an entirely new space for this vital work.
Woodson’s goals in founding the association were twofold. He wanted to establish Black history as a “scientific, rigorous field of study in the U.S. historical profession and in mainstream higher education,” Dagbovie says. But his intended audience wasn’t limited to academics. Woodson wanted to educate ordinary Black Americans, whom he believed had been indoctrinated to think of themselves as inferior.
“Taught the same economics, history, philosophy, literature and religion which have established the present code of morals, the Negro’s mind has been brought under the control of his oppressor,” Woodson wrote in his landmark 1933 book, The Mis-Education of the Negro. “The problem of holding the Negro down, therefore, is easily solved. When you control a man’s thinking, you do not have to worry about his actions. You do not have to tell him not to stand here or go yonder. He will find his ‘proper place’ and will stay in it.”
Writing in 1940, Woodson declared that “the past of the Negro race has been so obscured and belittled by propagandists that little is known of its creditable record.” Through the association and its assorted publications, including the Journal of Negro History and the Negro History Bulletin, he sought “to collect the records of the Negro and treat them scientifically”—a mandate he fulfilled by publishing original scholarship on Black history, assorted documents testifying to the experiences of the formerly enslaved and textbookish overviews aimed at a more general Black audience.
Woodson believed that the publicization of Black history would benefit white Americans, too. As Dagbovie explains, the historian hoped that “if white people knew about Black people’s accomplishments going back to the shores of Africa, they would recognize their humanity … and not discriminate against them.”
Woodson in Washington, D.C.
In 1918, Woodson moved to the nation’s capital, where he taught at a local high school before accepting a position as the dean of liberal arts at the historically Black Howard University. Four years after his arrival in Washington, Woodson retired from teaching to dedicate his time to the association. He purchased a three-story rowhouse in Washington’s Shaw neighborhood, selecting the location based on its “proximity to other well-known Black institutions: Black schools, Black churches, Black businesses,” says Fowler.
The house served as the headquarters of the Associated Publishers, a company founded by Woodson in 1921 to publish the work of Black writers. It also acted as the base of operations for Woodson’s association and its publications. The historian lived on the building’s third floor and used the second floor as an office and library. In the basement, he stored a trove of documents related to Black history.
Now a National Park Service historic site, the Carter G. Woodson Home “served as a training ground for other up-and-coming historians and scholars,” Fowler says. “It served as a library, a warehouse of books. It served as a repository of important documents in not just Black history, but the history of Black people or people of African descent. Most importantly, the home served as the birthplace of Black History Month.” (The historic site is closed for renovations but is expected to reopen later this year.)
Woodson was a prominent figure in local Black circles, mingling with and mentoring other scholars, including Black women like Mary McLeod Bethune. When his organization ran low on money—a common occurrence, especially after Woodson stopped receiving funding from white philanthropists in the 1930s—“he relied heavily on … the support of the Black community, regular, everyday people, giving to the association” to keep it operational, Fowler says. “Whatever money he earned, he put back into the association, he put back into the house, he put back into the Black history movement.”
Did you know? Carter G. Woodson and Mary McLeod Bethune
- Black educator and activist Mary McLeod Bethune served as the first female president of the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History between 1936 and 1951.
- Following Woodson’s death in 1950, Bethune—who counted the historian as a close friend and mentor—eulogized him by saying, “He helped me to maintain faith in myself. He gave me renewed confidence in the capacity of my race.”
The first Negro History Week
Woodson announced the first Negro History Week in 1926, timing the celebration to coincide with the February birthdays of Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglass. The event aimed to document Black lives “from American slavery to freedom and to fill the historical gaps deliberately overlooked to miseducate our children,” says ASALH President Karsonya Wise Whitehead in an email.
“Negro History Week was the first major achievement in popularizing Black history and was unique in in that it focused on the Black youth,” writes Dagbovie in The Early Black History Movement, Carter G. Woodson and Lorenzo Johnston Greene. Woodson had “realized that the miseducation of Black people began in their homes, communities and elementary schools, and he targeted these sites aggressively, focusing especially on the schools.”
Although Woodson’s initial proposal of a weeklong celebration was relatively modest in scope, his underlying goal was to “integrate the study of Black history into American culture, particularly in K-12 education,” Dagbovie says.
Woodson believed that “there can be no celebration without education,” Fowler says. Far from limiting lessons on Black history to this single week, Woodson wanted students to gather information throughout the year and use this time to share summaries or snippets of what they’d learned, Fowler explains. “He felt that eventually, there will be no need for a Negro History Week because Black history will be studied along with other history.”
The public response to Negro History Week exceeded Woodson’s expectations. “Letters poured in from teachers across the country eager to incorporate more Black history into their classrooms,” Meghelli says. “Communities organized Black history lectures, banquets, poetry readings, exhibits and student contests. That enthusiasm only grew over the years and decades.”
By the 1940s, writes biographer Jacqueline Goggin in Carter G. Woodson: A Life in Black History, Negro History Week celebrations had become “increasingly sophisticated and well attended.” The association even sold kits featuring posters, photos and teaching materials for use in classrooms. But not until 1976, when ASALH urged President Gerald R. Ford to issue a proclamation encouraging Americans to commemorate Black History Month, was the celebration officially extended from a week to a full month. Congress formalized this recognition a decade later, passing a law that designated February as “National Black (Afro American) History Month.”
Dagbovie says that the Negro History Week events held during Woodson’s lifetime were “probably more effective than the Black History Months” of today. Back then, he adds, students were actively “involved in doing the learning themselves, rather than just being shown something or asked to watch a special documentary. Even the marketing of Black History Month now, it’s become very commercialized in many ways.”
Woodson’s legacy
When Woodson died in 1950, at age 74, Du Bois praised his establishment of Negro History Week as a “crowning achievement.” An erstwhile colleague of Woodson’s, Du Bois wrote, “I know of no one man who in a lifetime has, unaided, built up such a national celebration.”
Du Bois’ obituary wasn’t wholly positive. Criticizing Woodson as “a cramped soul” who lacked geniality and humor, Du Bois wrote that “in his death, he does not leave many very warm friends; there were few tears shed at his grave. But on the other hand, among American Negroes, and among those whites who knew about his work, and among those who in after years must learn about it, there will be vast respect and thankfulness for the life of this man.”
At least one of Woodson’s friends objected to Du Bois’ characterization. Still, Dagbovie acknowledges that Woodson could be a difficult friend and colleague. He was single-mindedly focused on the promotion of Black history, which “became his life’s work, almost an obsession,” Fowler says. “He did not have a personal life in the sense of kids, family.”
Overall, Dagbovie summarizes Woodson’s legacy as “tangible,” adding, “He left behind institutions that still exist today and thrive.” The association and its journal, for example, continue to operate under slightly different branding. But Negro History Week and its successor, Black History Month, are perhaps the most visible, enduring reminders of Woodson’s lifework.
“Black History Month continues to serve us well,” wrote Smithsonian Secretary Bunch in the 2015 blog post, “in part because Woodson’s creation is as much about today as it is about the past. Experiencing Black History Month every year reminds us that history is not dead or distant from our lives. … It helps us to remember there is no more powerful force than a people steeped in their history. And there is no higher cause than honoring our struggle and ancestors by remembering.”
Learn about Woodson’s legacy by visiting the Carter G. Woodson Home National Historic Site in Washington, D.C. when it reopens later this year. You can also find out more about the “father of Black history” at sites along the U.S. Civil Rights Trail, including the National Museum of African American History and Culture and Berea College in Kentucky.

They might be the first animals known to fake a floral scent

articles.content:
These Parasitic Beetles Mimic the Smell of Flowers So They Can Trick Bees and Raid Their Nests, New Research Suggests
They might be the first animals known to fake a floral scent
A beetle species’ larvae seem to bamboozle bees by smelling like flowers. This newly discovered deceptive strategy might be the first known example of an animal imitating floral scents, according to a study posted January 15 on the preprint server bioRxiv. It has not been peer-reviewed
The trickery works like this: Larvae of the European black oil beetle (Meloe proscarabaeus) ascend grasses and cluster together, taking on the appearance of orange flowers, and produce floral-smelling compounds. When a fooled bee approaches them, the larvae latch onto the pollinator and ride back to its nest—where they feast on bee eggs.
“It’s a beautiful study,” says Consuelo De Moraes, a chemical ecologist at ETH Zürich who was not involved in the work, to Erik Stokstad at Science. “It’s amazing to me how sophisticated these interactions are.”
Parasitic beetles use a range of tricks to lure bees. For example, one species emits female bee sex pheromones to attract a specific type of male bee, while another species perches atop flowers and waits for pollinators to gather nectar. But European black oil beetle larvae were known to form strange clumps and chow down on a wide variety of hosts, leading the researchers behind the new work to hypothesize that the insects employ a unique strategy.
So, the team collected adult European black oil beetles in Germany in the spring of 2024 and 2025 and kept them in greenhouse tanks until they mated. The females laid thousands of eggs that hatched a few weeks later. Then, the larvae climbed up grass stems, and the researchers gathered the young creatures for chemical analysis.
The work revealed that the larvae emit 17 compounds that are often found in flowers but are rare in insects. These include linalool oxide and lilac aldehyde, which are known to draw in pollinators. “It wasn’t just that [the beetles] were producing one compound and then loosely trying to mimic a flower,” says study co-author Ryan Alam, a synthetic chemist at the Max Planck Institute for Chemical Ecology in Germany, to Richard Kemeny at Science News. “It was like their own personal larval perfume.”
Did you know? Plants play tricks too
Animals are far from the only deceptive organisms. Many plants also trick creatures into doing their bidding. For instance, the black-bulb yam seems to produce plump, fake berries to trick birds into spreading its offspring, according to a recent study.
Then, Alam and his colleagues made their own blends of larvae-emitted scents to see how bees would respond. The four tested bee species preferred synthetic beetle perfume to wheatgrass, which was used as a control.
The compounds also attracted the larvae, the team found, which suggests that the odor might tell the young ones to gather atop plant stems in early spring, before most flowers bloom. This, the authors note in the study, points to an “intriguing evolutionary scenario” where the larvae may have once been drawn to flowers and then evolved to produce a strong scent themselves, cutting out the need for the natural floral signal.
May Berenbaum, an entomologist at the University of Illinois Urbana–Champaign who was not involved in the study, tells Science that researchers probably find chemical forms of deception less often than visual forms because humans see better than they smell. But, she adds, more examples will likely emerge with dedicated efforts.
“It takes really careful observation and intuition to figure out some of these very strange relationships,” Berenbaum says.

articles.content:
Physicists Create Homemade Cosmic Dust, Which Could Help Them Figure Out How the Building Blocks of Life First Reached Earth
Cosmic dust normally comes from dying stars. The recipe for a lab-made version includes a few gases, vacuum tubes and electricity
Tiny specks of rock, ice, minerals or other chemical compounds float freely throughout the universe. This so-called cosmic dust contains ingredients crucial to the formation of stars, planets, comets and even people.
Now, using gases and electricity to mimic the harsh environment of space, physicists have concocted their own lab-made version of cosmic dust. The work, described in a study published January 30 in the Astrophysical Journal, could help researchers investigate how elements crucial for life reached Earth, and simulate how life might pop up elsewhere in the cosmos.
“It’s like we have recreated a little bit of the universe in a bottle in our lab,” says study co-author Linda Losurdo, a physicist at the University of Sydney in Australia, in a statement.
Researchers suspect that cosmic dust comes from dying stars. A giant one near the end of its life will grow very hot around its exterior, begin to break apart and “belch out … huge waves of carbon,” Losurdo tells the Guardian’s Donna Lu. It also expels hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen, and all the elements get bombarded by high-energy particles. This creates chemical reactions and results in what are called CHON molecules, which play key roles in the foundations of life.
Did you know? Stars create elements
These huge balls of gas are element factories. Massive stars convert lighter elements, such as helium and carbon, into heavier ones, like neon, magnesium and iron, via nuclear fusion. They release the elements when they explode in bright supernovas.
The stuff burped up by stars is “quite similar” to the materials found in meteorites, Losurdo tells the Guardian. Researchers often rely on these space rocks to study CHON molecules and answer questions such as how these molecules got to Earth. Some hypotheses include that they formed on the planet during its youth, were dropped off later by comets and meteorites, came during the solar system’s birth about 4.6 billion years ago or originated from some combination of the three.
But meteorites are rare commodities, as most that fall to Earth burn up in the planet’s atmosphere before reaching the surface.
So, Losurdo and David McKenzie, also a physicist at the University of Sydney, added nitrogen, carbon dioxide and acetylene, a gas with carbon and hydrogen, to tubes with air vacuumed out, mimicking outer space. Then, they blasted the gases with 10,000 volts of electrical potential for roughly an hour, creating plasma.
“You’re completing a circuit across the gas itself, so the gas is getting excited, electrons are flying off, creating an environment in which things want to bind and coalesce and aggregate,” Losurdo tells CNN’s Jacopo Prisco. “And that’s a very natural process. It’s something that we know for certain happens around stars.”
The energy sparked chemical reactions that created new compounds, including cosmic dust, which fell onto silicon wafers inside the tubes. Further analysis revealed that the lab-made dust emitted infrared light signatures similar to space-made dust, as previously detected by telescopes.
The new research is “a really beautiful method” that creates a substance similar to “what we think interstellar dust is like,” Sara Webb, an astrophysicist at Swinburne University in Australia who was not involved in the study, tells the Guardian.
“One very exciting possibility, which is probably further down the track, is … to use this kind of simulated cosmic dust in other organic chemistry experiments, to simulate early life formation on different types of planets,” she adds.
Damanveer Grewal, a cosmochemist at Yale University who was not involved in the study, tells CNN in an email that the new work bridges an important gap between telescopic observations and laboratory analysis.
It can also be used as a jumping-off point to test ideas about the origins of organics in space, he notes. “The findings suggest that complex organic matter forms readily in stellar environments and is not unique to our solar system,” Grewal says. “If these materials are widespread, it implies that the essential chemical building blocks for life are likely available to planetary systems throughout the galaxy.”

articles.title: Rumors Suggested That Anne Boleyn Was a Witch With Six Fingers. Did This Elizabethan Artist Rework a Portrait of the Tudor Queen to Debunk the Gossip?
articles.author: Redação
articles.excerpt:
Rumors Suggested That Anne Boleyn Was a Witch With Six Fingers. Did This Elizabethan Artist Rework a Portrait of the Tudor Queen to Debunk the Gossip?
A new analysis of the Hever Rose portrait...
articles.content:
Rumors Suggested That Anne Boleyn Was a Witch With Six Fingers. Did This Elizabethan Artist Rework a Portrait of the Tudor Queen to Debunk the Gossip?
A new analysis of the Hever Rose portrait suggests that the painter deliberately modified an existing template to showcase Anne’s hands—with no extra digits—holding a delicate rose
In 1585, a Catholic priest living in exile published an unflattering description of Anne Boleyn, the mother of England’s reigning Protestant queen, Elizabeth I.
Anne, who’d been executed on charges of treason in 1536, had “an oval face of a sallowish complexion, as if troubled with jaundice,” the priest wrote. “She had a projecting tooth under the upper lip, and on her right hand six fingers.”
This purported extra finger—a characteristic sometimes associated with witchcraft during the early modern era—provided fuel for Elizabeth’s critics, who viewed her claim to the English throne as tenuous. (She’d been declared a bastard following her mother’s execution.)
Drawing on now-debunked accounts of Anne’s physical appearance, Catholics accused her of witchcraft, heresy and scandalous conduct, engaging in a “widespread and vicious” assassination of her character, writes historian Tracy Borman in Anne Boleyn and Elizabeth I: The Mother and Daughter Who Forever Changed British History. That negative reputation persisted for centuries.
Now, new research conducted for an exhibition at Anne’s childhood home, Hever Castle in Kent, England, reveals an early effort to rehabilitate the Tudor queen’s image. As Dalya Alberge reports for the Guardian, infrared analysis of the late 16th-century Hever Rose portrait of Anne shows that its creator deliberately reworked an existing template to show both of her hands.
“By clearly displaying five digits on each hand, the portrait acts as a visual rebuttal to hostile rumors and as a defense of Anne Boleyn—and, by extension, of her daughter Elizabeth’s legitimacy,” says Owen Emmerson, an assistant curator at Hever Castle, in a statement.
Did you know? Anne Boleyn and witchcraft
- Contrary to popular belief, witchcraft wasn’t one of the charges leveled against Anne during her trial. Instead, the second wife of Henry VIII faced contrived accusations of adultery, incest and conspiring to kill the king.
- In a 2023 journal article, historian Sylvia Barbara Soberton addressed many of the misconceptions surrounding the Tudor queen and witchcraft. She argued that Nicholas Sander, the Catholic priest who wrote the disparaging description of Anne, never actually described her as a witch, instead criticizing her for the crime of heresy. His words were later misconstrued due to an inaccurate translation.
- At the same time, Soberton pointed out that rumors of Anne practicing witchcraft circulated both during her lifetime and in the decades following her execution.
During the Tudor era, which lasted from 1485 to 1603, artists often based their likenesses of royals on preapproved templates or “face patterns” instead of painting from life. This practice—which proved particularly popular during Elizabeth’s nearly 45-year reign—helped monarchs assert control over their public personas and avoid the time-consuming process of sitting for portraits in person.
The Hever Rose portrait is based on a template known as the “B” pattern, which is perhaps best exemplified by an iconic image of Anne housed at the National Portrait Gallery in London. In this pattern, Anne is typically portrayed from the bust up, with a pearl “B” necklace around her neck and her hands out of view. Infrared reflectography scans taken at the Hamilton Kerr Institute at the University of Cambridge capture the moment when the Hever Rose artist decided to deviate from this established template by featuring Anne’s hands, which are shown clasping a rose.
“This preliminary design was laid down with confident, continuous lines, indicating that it was transferred from a pre-existing pattern rather than drawn freehand,” Emmerson tells the Daily Mail’s Wiliam Hunter. “At a later stage, however, the artist altered this plan. Anne’s hands were added in, cutting across the earlier design.”
In addition to analyzing the infrared scans, the Hever team performed a dendrochronology assessment of the portrait, dating the oak panel on which it was painted to around 1583. At the time, Elizabeth’s “legitimacy, succession and ancestry were under renewed pressure,” Emmerson told Smithsonian magazine earlier this year, and rumors about her mother’s supposed misdeeds ran rampant.
The pope had excommunicated Elizabeth in 1570, giving her Catholic subjects and fellow monarchs license to overthrow her. This situation was “compounded by the fact that she’s no longer of child-bearing age, she’s unmarried … so she cannot look to the future to promote her legitimacy,” Emmerson told the Independent’s Harry Cockburn last month. Critics of the Protestant queen looked to her Catholic cousin Mary, Queen of Scots, as a viable claimant to the English throne.
Given the timeframe of the Hever Rose portrait’s creation, Emmerson and exhibition co-curator Kate McCaffrey argue that “the artist was directed to alter the established pattern specifically to show Anne’s hands, carefully and unmistakably,” per the statement. Although McCaffrey tells the Guardian that “it’s impossible to say” whether Elizabeth herself commissioned this portrait, she believes that it’s “too much of a coincidence for it not to be in response to rumors.”
McCaffrey adds, “It’s Elizabeth’s way of not only reclaiming her own legitimacy and lineage but also restoring the legitimacy of her mother.”
Historian Helene Harrison first observed the potential connection between the Hever Rose portrait and the Catholic priest’s claims in her 2025 book, The Many Faces of Anne Boleyn: Interpreting Image and Perception. As Harrison writes in a blog post, “Anne’s [hands] seem deliberately splayed, almost as a message.”
The Hever Rose news isn’t the only explosive revelation shared in recent weeks by the castle’s curators. In January, Emmerson announced the results of a technical analysis performed by Lawrence Hendra, an art historian at Philip Mould & Company, who identified four paintings—portraits of Anne and Elizabeth, as well as Elizabeth’s half-sister, Mary I, and her paternal great-grandfather, Edward IV—as the work of the same artist. The four sitters share “the same underlying facial geometry,” despite the fact that they weren’t all genetically related, Emmerson told Smithsonian. (Anne was linked to Mary and Edward through her marriage to Elizabeth’s father, Henry VIII.)
As Emmerson explained to the London Times’ Richard Brooks last month, the artist may have used the same facial template for each of the four portraits, cutting and pasting Elizabeth’s face onto those of her predecessors “to show a legitimate and God-ordained line of succession.”
Viewed together, the new analyses testify to a time of crisis during Elizabeth’s reign. Besieged by threats to her throne—including multiple plots to replace her with Mary, Queen of Scots—Elizabeth looked to portraiture as a powerful propaganda tool to spread messages emphasizing her resemblance to past monarchs and subtly disavowing falsehoods about her mother.
Overall, the Hever Castle exhibition seeks to move past the many myths surrounding Anne by bringing together more than 30 likenesses of her.
“Very few portraits of Anne Boleyn have undergone this level of scientific study,” says Emmerson in the statement. “By combining technical analysis with historical context, this exhibition brings us closer to seeing Anne as her contemporaries might have done—not as a myth, but as a real woman.”
“Capturing a Queen: The Image of Anne Boleyn” will be on view at Hever Castle & Gardens in Hever, England, from February 11, 2026, to January 2, 2027.

articles.content:
This Carved, Painted Zapotec Tomb Is Mexico’s Most Important Archaeological Discovery in a Decade
The tomb features the carvings of a huge owl head and at least three probable ancestors
Archaeologists in Mexico have uncovered an incredibly well-preserved Zapotec tomb dating back to the early seventh century. The tomb boasts intricately carved walls, murals and sculptures—including a massive owl, a Zapotec symbol of night and death.
It’s the “most significant archaeological discovery in a decade in Mexico,” said Mexico’s president, Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo, at a January press conference, per Live Science’s Kristina Killgrove.
Researchers unearthed the tomb in the valleys of central Oaxaca, a state in southern Mexico, according to a translated statement from Mexico’s National Institute of Anthropology and History (INAH). Officials were clued into the tomb’s location by an anonymous report of looting at the site, per Live Science. Oaxaca is the native land of the Zapotecs—also called the “Cloud People”—a pre-Hispanic population who have lived among its highlands and valleys since the sixth century B.C.E.
The entrance of the stone tomb’s antechamber, its small front room, is decorated with a complex sculpted portrait. A large owl head protrudes from the overdoor, its curved beak open, and inside its mouth is the sculpted, painted face of a man wearing wide hoop earrings. Per the statement, the man was likely a Zapotec lord—perhaps the ancestor to whom the tomb was dedicated.
The entrance is flanked by intricately carved, painted door jambs, one depicting a woman and the other a man. Each figure holds artifacts and wears a cloak, skirt and large headdress. According to a video from INAH, these full-length portraits may depict other ancestors buried in the tomb. But they could also represent the tomb’s guardians, per the statement.
Inside the antechamber is another doorway, leading into the burial chamber. Above this doorway is a frieze of engraved tombstones carved with “calendrical names,” per the statement. The ancient Zapotec calendar, composed of 260 days divided into 20 months, represented days through animals and other natural images. The people used the calendar to name gods and important people: Each was identified by a specific symbol associated with their birth date, reports Live Science.
The walls of the burial chamber are covered in murals. Painted in ochre, white, red, green and blue, the murals depict a parade of people walking toward the entrance of the tomb. The people carry bags of copal, resin from tropical trees that Mesoamericans—including Zapotecs, Maya and Aztecs—commonly burned during ceremonies.
Ancient Zapotec tombs are reputed for their intricate construction and decoration. In 2023, five 2,000-year-old Zapotec tombs were unearthed in Oaxaca. One of them was composed of multiple chambers arranged in a cross-shape, and it was decorated with red and yellow murals depicting warfare.
Quick facts: The tombs at Monte Albán
- Also in Oaxaca is Monte Albán, which was the capital of Zapotec society between about 500 B.C.E. and 850 C.E.
- Monte Albán’s sprawling ruins include plazas, pyramids, a ball court, tunnels and likely hundreds of tombs. These elaborate ancient funerary chambers are spacious, vibrantly painted and filled with riches.
Researchers are conserving, studying and protecting the recently discovered tomb, per the statement. This includes stabilizing the mural paints, which are vulnerable to degradation from roots, insects and environment changes. To learn more about the Zapotec rituals and funerary practices associated with the tomb, researchers are analyzing its inscriptions, ceramics and iconography.
Claudia Curiel de Icaza, Mexico’s secretary of culture, said at the press conference that the tomb is an “exceptional discovery” for what it says about Zapotec culture and “its social organization, funeral rituals and belief system, preserved by the architecture and the murals,” per CNN’s Jack Guy.
Curiel de Icaza recently visited the tomb, alongside local residents, INAH researchers and the governor of Oaxaca, report La Jornada’s Ana Mónica Rodríguez and Jorge A. Pérez. Before entering the chambers, Curiel de Icaza blessed its entrance by pouring a shot of mezcal on the floor.
One INAH researcher paused at the entrance, realizing they would be entering a tomb that doesn’t belong to them, La Jornada reports. The researcher raised their hands and asked permission of the wind, earth and Zapotecs to enter.

articles.author: Zoë Randolph
articles.excerpt: Some people love it, some people hate it, and some people are just here for the February 15 candy sales. Before Cupidâs arrow leaves you distracted, here are 20 things you might not know about...
articles.content:
Some people love it, some people hate it, and some people are just here for the February 15 candy sales. Before Cupidâs arrow leaves you distracted, here are 20 things you might not know about Valentineâs Day.
- Valentineâs Day dates back to ancient Rome.
- No one is entirely sure who St. Valentine was (or â¦ were?).
- St. Valentine is the saint of more than lovers.
- A pope initiated Valentineâs Day to tamp down âun-Christianâ celebrations.
- Geoffrey Chaucer made the first reference to Valentineâs Day as a romantic holiday.
- The first valentineâs note was sent in 1477.
- Cards and gifts became popular in the Middle Ages.
- Esther Howland pioneered the modern Valentineâs Day card.
- The first heart-shaped chocolate boxes appeared for Valentineâs Day in 1861.
- The Victorians sent rude cards on Valentineâs Day.
- Hallmark started mass-producing Valentineâs Day cards in 1913.
- People send more cards for Valentineâs Day than almost any other holiday.
- Valentineâs Day rakes in billions of dollars per year.
- Candy is the most common Valentineâs Day gift.
- During the COVID-19 pandemic, Valentineâs Day jewelry sales spiked.
- Six million people get engaged on Valentineâs Day.
- Valentineâs Day looks different around the world.
- Valentineâs Day is the most common wedding anniversary in the Philippines.
- Two territories became U.S. states on Valentineâs Day.
- Despite all the hoopla, Americans are apathetic about Valentineâs Day.
Valentineâs Day dates back to ancient Rome.
If you showed up in Rome on February 14 with a bouquet of roses, say, 2000 years ago, youâd probably get some confused looks. Youâd be right in your assumption that youâd arrived on a holidayâin fact, Romans would have been midway through a three-day party known as the Feast of Lupercalia. But suffice it to say, roses were not involved.
Participants in the multi-day affair âwere drunk. They were naked,â CU Boulder historian Noel Lenski told NPR. Oh, and did we mention that the men also sacrificed goats and dogs, then slapped women with the hides? The practice was supposed to aid fertility. The juryâs still out on whether being presented with a box of heart-shaped chocolates or being whipped with the skin of a recently deceased goat is more conducive to baby-making.
No one is entirely sure who St. Valentine was (or â¦ were?).
Who exactly are we referencing when we call ourselves someoneâs âvalentine?â Much like the nature of love itself, itâs largely a mystery.
Some say St. Valentine was a priest and physician who lived in Rome and was killed by Emperor Claudius II around 270 CE after being discovered secretly wedding lovers as a tactic to get the men out of military service. However, he may also have been a bishop in Terni, Italy. Adding to the fun, itâs also possible that these two stories refer to the same person. Plus, there was yet another Valentine who lived in Africa and met an unfortunate February end.
In all the confusion, the Catholic Church took St. Valentine off the General Roman Calendar back in 1969, though it continues to recognize him (whoever he may be) as a saint.
St. Valentine is the saint of more than lovers.
